results.title: The Bugaku dance
results.brief_description: An introduction to “Bugaku” or Japanese Imperial Court dance and music, which have been preserved in the Imperial Court for centuries. It contains performances of “Ryoo”, a solo dance played with the use of masks, and “Bairo”, a mass dance. Music only - no narration.

results.title: The Buddhist world
results.brief_description: Reviews the origins of Buddhism through the life, work, and philosophy of Gautama Buddha; gives an understanding of the major doctrines of Buddhist belief; traces the historical and cultural growth of Buddhism, and shows its influence in those lands where it is practiced today - India, Thailand, Japan and Tibet.

results.title: The Buddha of suburbia
results.creator_credit: Roger Michell, Kevin Loader and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A four-part British miniseries about the life of the Amir family who live in the suburbs of 1970s London, and in particular, Karim (Naveen Andrews) whose whole teenage existence is turned upside down during this decade of sex, drugs, politics, racism and rock ‘n’ roll. Karim’s mother Margaret (Brenda Blethyn) is English, his father Haroon (Roshan Seth) is Indian and he has a younger brother Allie (Assam Mamodeally). The family is suddenly thrown into turmoil when Haroon tosses in his job as a civil servant and turns to the life of a suburban guru, leaving his wife and family for the more free-spirited Eva (Susan Fleetwood). The story follows Karim and his relationships as he embarks on a career as a stage actor, weaving from one sub-plot to the next with an array of stereotype characters, situations, humour, including several explicit sex scenes along the way. Explores themes of culture and cross-culture, tradition versus liberation and the anti-Asian racism of London in the seventies. Based on the novel by Hanif Kureishi with screenplay by Hanif Kureishi and Roger Michell. Incidental music and title song composed by David Bowie, performed by David Bowie and Erdal Kizikay. Cast includes Steven Mackintosh, Harish Patel, John McEnery, Janet Dale, David Bamber, Donald Sumpter and Nisha Nayar.

results.title: The Buddha of Badamtam
results.creator_credit: Murad Ali, Biresh Paul and Afsana Babylon
results.brief_description: This documentary traces the journey of Indian artist Meera Mukherjee’s conception of a fourteen-foot high bronze Buddha sculpture in the Himalayas, a testament to great art and a message of peace. Filmmaker Murad Ali focuses on Mukherjee’s lifelong interest in Buddhism and the spiritual quest that took her to Ladakh, Lahaul, Spiti, and Japan in search of answers, attempting to reconcile Buddhism and art. Roshan Seth and Nafisa Ali Sodhi narrate the film, which intersperses black and white footage of Mukherjee at work with colour stills, and features some stunning Indian singing. When Mukherjee died whilst working on the piece on January 27, 1998, a slew of artisans laboured to complete and erect the enormous work.

results.title: The Bruce Petty collection
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Bruce Petty, Ron Saunders, Robin Hughes, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is a unique collection of films that have been devised, written or directed by renowned cartoonist/filmmaker Bruce Petty for Film Australia. Multi-award winning LEISURE (14 mins, 1976) is an animated and lighthearted look at the worlds of work and leisure. It considers our changing patterns of work since life began and the effects the Industrial Revolution has had on our leisure time. (OSCAR for Best Animated Short Subject, 49th Academy Awards, Los Angeles, 1977). MEGALOMEDIA (28 mins, 1981) is a humorous, yet at the same time searching sweep through the development of media and its audiences. Max Gillies guides the audience through a rapid succession of thoughts and perceptions in three parts Media Machine, Media Market and Media Mind. Important issues are raised in an entertaining manner. In THE MOVERS (49 mins, 1987) the development of technology is examined; from the primitive age through to the nuclear age. It examines technology’s relationship with human beings and the human cost of the gap that is created between countries that are technologically advanced and those that are not.

results.title: The Brown dressing gown
results.brief_description: Patric fondly remembers his social worker Julie Wilson who helped him come out of his cocoon and discard his brown dressing gown. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and The Deafness Foundation.

results.title: The Brothers Quay. Vol. 01
results.brief_description: The eerie and often disturbing animated films of The Brothers Quay have intrigued audiences around the world both for the extent of imagination they display and their challenge to conventional notions of animation. US born (in 1947) but London based, Stephen and Timothy Quay make the puppets, construct the sets, arrange the lighting and do the camerawork for their mini-masterpieces. Their work is utterly unique and personal yet is, at the same time, suffused with the influence of Eastern European animation, art, literature and music. This compilation contains “The Unnameable little broom”, “The Cabinet of Jan Svankmajer” and their most famous work, “Street of crocodiles”.

results.title: The Brothers Karamazov
results.creator_credit: Richard Brooks, Pandro S. Berman, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Avon
results.brief_description: Based on Dostoyevsky’s masterful story of greed, vindictiveness and lust, “The Brothers Karamazov” brings 19th century Czarist Russia to life in a lavish dramatic production. Karamazov, is the father of four wildly disparate sons: a sterile intellectual, the saintly Alexey, an illegitimate schemer and the feckless oldest son, Dmitri who is in love with the same elusive woman as his father. They all stand to gain an inheritance from their father and together they weave a web of intrigue and murder. A wonderfully woven tale of sin and salvation, the film stars Yul Brynner, Maria Schell, Lee J. Cobb, Claire Bloom, Richard Basehart and William Shatner.

results.title: The Brothers Byrne
results.creator_credit: William Gough, Rex Tasker, Ian McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Torn between the world of their childhood and the world where they must mow live and work, two flamboyant Newfoundlanders pay a nostalgic visit to the deserted outport where they were born. This is their story, and the story of so many others who, like them, became victims of the Newfoundland government’s controversial Resettlement Program. Credits include: Photography by Kent Nason.
